pageContext.title: 8 rising startups in Southeast Asia you need to look at
pageContext.content:
Which are the startups that are on the path to becoming the next big thing? In this regular post, we give you an overview of the companies that have raised money in the past week, as well as those that we think investors should look at. Want your startup featured on this list? Details below.

1. Chilindo (Thailand)

Chilindo is an ecommerce startup that combines an auction model with tight supply chain management to bring affordable goods to consumers. Its revenue has grown rapidly from US$1 million in 2014 to US$85 million and more than a thousand employees in 2017.

Source: Tech in Asia

2. RWDC (Singapore)

RWDC develops innovative and cost-effective biopolymer material solutions. In particular, the company produces medium-chain-length PHAs, which are naturally produced by bacterial fermentation of plant-based oils or sugar, and are widely recognized as the world’s only commercially viable biodegradable bioplastic due to its versatility.

Amount raised: US$13 million
Round: Series A2
Investors: Co-led by venture capital firms Vickers Venture Partners and WI Harper Group. Finance firm Ridgevale Enterprises Limited also participated
Source: Tech in Asia

3. Gogoprint (Thailand)

Gogoprint is an online service for printing things like business cards, flyers, and leaflets. It uses algorithms that take into account parameters such as paper type, quantity, and delivery, and then aggregates those orders into a “print-run” or a batch of prints.

Amount raised: US$7.7 million
Round: Series A
Investors:  Led by its existing backer OPG (Online Printing Group), an investor and partner of Brazil-based Printi.
Source: Tech in Asia

4. TabSquare (Singapore)

TabSquare uses AI to make personalized menu recommendations and improve customers’ ability to order, pay, and deliver feedback. It has deployed 6,000 devices that serve more than 12 million diners and 6 million orders annually.

Amount raised: US$7.2 million
Round: Series A2
Investors: Led by Japanese comparison shopping website operator Kakaku.com. The round is supported by Coca-Cola Amatil, Resorts World, and existing investor Walden International.
Source: Tech in Asia

5. Republic Protocol (Singapore)

Republic Protocol is an open-source decentralized dark pool exchange that facilitates cross-chain atomic trades on a hidden order book over the Ethereum and Bitcoin networks. The startup has raised over US$30 million.

Source: Tech in Asia

6. Dekoruma (Indonesia)

Although the company started out selling furniture, Dekoruma has now developed a new interior design feature. Homeowners will be paired with appropriate interior designers. If the design has been made, they can connect with third parties who can do mechanical, electrical, and construction work.

Amount raised: Several million US dollars
Round: Series B
Investors: Led by Global Digital Niaga (the company behind ecommerce site Blibli) and AddVentures, an investment company owned by Thai conglomerate Siam Cement Group.
Source: Tech in Asia

7. Waresix (Indonesia)

Founded in 2017, Waresix built a marketplace that connects businesses and individuals in need of warehouse space with warehouse operators. The site allows users to book a wide range of storage options in less than 24 hours. It also provides cross-border warehousing services for overseas customers looking to distribute goods to Indonesia.

Amount raised: US$1.6 million
Round: Bridge
Investors:  Led by East Ventures and Monk’s Hill Ventures
Source: Tech in Asia

8. Wallex (Singapore)

Wallex offers solutions such as virtual accounts (for collections and disbursements), a multi-currency wallet, foreign exchange (forex) conversions, cross-border payments, and an API with real-time forex execution capability. These tools allow SMEs to manage their cash and hedge their forex risk with convenience through a single platform.

Amount raised: Undisclosed
Round: Bridge
Investors: Beenext took the lead, with Central Capital Ventura and Indonusa Dwitama, an early investor in Tokopedia, joining in.
Source: Tech in Asia

Is your startup headquartered in Southeast Asia? Want your startup to be featured in future editions of this list? Here are the steps:

  1. Check if your startup’s profile already exists on Tech in Asia through our company search feature.
  2. Go to the create a company profile page. You’ll need an account to be able to do so. Fill out the name of your company. If your company profile is already in our database, you have the option of claiming it and modifying the details. If your company profile doesn’t exist, please create one.
  3. Fill out this form with your startup’s details. We’ll review it when we make a new list.

Note that we have to be selective in the startups that we pick. That is because we generally want startups that might interest investors or venture capitalists. The Google form should give you an idea of what we’re looking out for. Good luck!

See previous rising startup lists here.

seo.title: 8 rising startups in Southeast Asia you need to look at
seo.description: Here are the startups that are on the path to becoming the next big thing?
